@evoskuil @hashamadeus That is precisely the fallacy. Bitcoin does conform to the Mises regression theory for money. Its "originary" use as a consumable is as a fee for writable space on the Blockchain. The write function may be a non-exchangeable timestamp.
@evoskuil @hashamadeus In other words, it is property in law only because it derives its value from its fiat legal decree. Intellectual property is in this category also.

@DominikBalogh @lightcoin Various non-equity structures of ICO tokens are not due to deception. They are a response to onerous restrictions by securities regulators.
Although digital bearer instruments, ICO tokens do not have the attributes of money. They are more like company tokens or protocol tokens.
With Bitcoin, what's actually under attack is the concept of monetary systems being under the domain of jurisdictional boundaries.
